Award.AwardTitle: Impacts of Climate Change and Ice Conditions on Microbial Food Web Dynamics in the Barents Sea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009
(Public Law 111-5).

This study aims to examine the relationships between the planktonic food web of the Barents Sea and changing sea-ice conditions. It would focus on the role of microzooplankton (MZP; 20 - 200 um in size), which have been suggested to be more important herbivores than the larger copepods in the tightly coupled food web of the Barents Sea, and would address the following questions:

1. What is the spatial distribution of phytoplankton and MZP standing stocks in response to the change in ice cover and sea temperature?
2. Do distinct water masses and ice cover determine the taxonomic composition of MZP in the Barents Sea?
3. What is the capacity of MZP to use primary production under different sea temperature/ice conditions?
4. What is the relative importance of heterotrophic protists in pelagic copepod diet under different ice/sea temperature/bloom combinations?

The PIs propose to address these questions by conducting five research cruises in the Barents Sea over three years to capture seasonal and interannual variability in microbial distribution and dynamics. Detailed data will be obtained on horizontal and vertical distributions of phytoplankton and MZP using a towed, high-resolution plankton survey system. These data will be related to hydrographic (ice cover, sea temperature, stratification), hydrochemical, and other biological variables. The program will directly involve a postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduates at an urban, minority-serving institution. In addition, the project team includes a professional science educator who will coordinate the production and dissemination of curriculum materials for grades 7-12 and the conduct of teacher workshops.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE The central goal of this project was to contribute to a Pan-Arctic perspective on the pelagic food web response to climate change by comparing microzooplankton (i.e. consumers <200 µm) composition, distribution, and trophic dynamics among different polar systems. In 2010-2013, the project researchers took part in nine expeditions to the Barents Sea, the Kara Sea, the Beaufort Gyre region of the Arctic Ocean, and the Northeast Passage aboard several research vessels and icebreakers. Plankton samples were collected from discrete depths at 160 stations representing a wide range of oceanographic conditions: ice-covered and open water, total depth from 10 m to 3,900 m, seawater temperatures from -1.8ºC to 12.0ºC, and salinity from 0.05 to 35.1‰. Trophic interaction between microzooplankton, phytoplankton, and pelagic copepods were examined in 63 shipboard incubation experiments in collaboration with polar scientists from the USA, Canada, Norway, and Russia. Samples were processed using state-of-the-art methods including digital video microscopy, flow-cytometry, and molecular genetics. The results of this study indicate that the microbial food web plays a central role in carbon cycling in the Arctic and predict a further increase in its importance with the rising sea temperatures. Microzooplankton controlled primary production in the three studied regions and demonstrated rapid growth at extreme polar temperatures. Combined with their quantitative importance, the remarkable ecological plasticity of these protists suggests that they may be contributing to the resilience of pelagic polar ecosystems to environmental perturbations. These results can be incorporated into physical-biological models and improve their predictive abilities with respect to the climate change impacts on polar food webs. The project findings were reported to the scientific community in twenty conference presentations and seminars. Several datasets were deposited with the ACADIS online data center. A post-doctoral scholar, a graduate student and five undergraduate students were trained, including three females. The project highlights and images were made available to the public via a dedicated web site. The PI participated in three public outreach events, including the WVIZ Ideastream distance learning program "From Plankton to Polar Bears: Understanding Global Climate Change", which involved eight Ohio schools. A multimedia show , including images of Arctic biota and the project research activities was incorporated into a temporary exhibit at the Great Lakes Science Center in Cleveland Ohio in association with the "To the Arctic" OMNIMAX movie. Based on science center attendance records, approximately 45,000 visitors encountered the exhibit. Last Modified: 12/24/2013 Submitted by: Peter J Lavrentyev
